jeopardy_round: YOU WILL BE TESTED ON THIS

(1, 1).clue: 25x = the number of U.S. Senate members

(2, 1).clue: This dual monarchy with a population of about 50 million was formed; it lasted until 1918

(3, 1).clue: Fabio won a Nobel Prize for chemistry: Fabio

(4, 1).clue: The Snellen chart tests these body parts; the top line is 20/400

(6, 1).clue: When asked how many husbands she's had, this Gabor sister said, "You mean apart from my own?"

(1, 2).clue: 99 - x = the number of keys on a standard piano

(2, 2).clue: In 1867, he published the play "Peer Gynt" and obviously spent some time on his facial hair

(3, 2).clue: A German's germs are not germane to a conversation about Jermaine Jackson: germane (with a "G")

(4, 2).clue: The Stanford-Binet V tests this in students

(6, 2).clue: In one of their shorts, a judge cries for order, to which Curly says, "I'll take a ham sandwich"

(2, 3).clue: The fame of this scout was spread by a Harper's article that went "wild" over his "exquisite manly proportions"

(3, 3).clue: The golf tourney was a success despite the trampling incident: despite

(4, 3).clue: In a Monty Python film, the test for identifying one of these is whether she weighs as much as a duck

(6, 3).clue: This fraternal funnyman quipped, "Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend.  Inside of a dog, it's too dark to read"

(2, 4).clue: August von Hofmann discovered this fluid; 25 years later it could have been used to embalm him

(3, 4).clue: Which of these Lederhosen brings out my eyes?: which

(4, 4).clue: Lichens provide the coloring for this, also a term for a crucial, revealing test

(6, 4).clue: This comic deadpanned, "I stayed up one night playing poker with tarot cards. I got a full house & 4 people died"

(1, 5).clue: 30 + x = Douglas Adams' ultimate answer to...well, everything

(2, 5).clue: She wed a doomed physician suffering from alcoholism, perhaps contributing to her violent hatred of booze

(3, 5).clue: Neither rain nor snow nor sleet shall keep me from my appointed rounds, but locusts? I'm out: nor

(4, 5).clue: Testing of blood serum helps diagnose this tick-borne ailment named for a range of peaks

(6, 5).clue: Noel Coward punned in a telegram: "coughing myself into a" this, the Italian name for Florence

(1, 1).clue: Today we pick this leaf of the laurel tree out of our food, but legend says oracles chewed it to promote visions

(2, 1).clue: Producer/director Garry & comic actress/ director Penny

(3, 1).clue: Many Mediterranean cruises embark from this second-largest Spanish city & major port

(4, 1).clue: This working model of a new product is usually built to full scale

(5, 1).clue: For the metal nickel, the mineral pentlandite is a major one of these sources

(6, 1).clue: In a nature poem Whittier rhymed, "The winding water's sounding rush, the long note of" this bird

(1, 2).clue: 19th century English pubs had containers of this spice from a root so that patrons could shake it into their ale

(3, 2).clue: The deepest part of the Mediterranean, over 16,000 feet, is just south of this country, in the Ionian basin

(4, 2).clue: From the Latin for "to know", it's a person with expert knowledge or training

(5, 2).clue: This commonest coarse-grained plutonic rock is desirable for countertops

(6, 2).clue: When this biblical king spares an ant hill, the Queen of Sheba realizes she knows "the secret of thy worth and wisdom"

(1, 3).clue: To show remorse after murdering his wife, Nero may have burned a year's supply of this spice that comes in quills

(3, 3).clue: You'll need a passport to gamble in the 149-year-old "Casino de" this location; locals aren't allowed

(4, 3).clue: In Marxist theory, members of this class of workers have no capital or property & must sell their labor to survive

(5, 3).clue: Naturally, plenty of coal was formed in this geologic period, 360 million to 300 million B.C.

(6, 3).clue: In "Snow-Bound" Whittier was "content to let" this "roar in baffled rage at pane and door"

(2, 4).clue: Julianne & Derek, of "Dancing with the Stars" fame

(3, 4).clue: Rising above the Mediterranean coast are these mountains that form the backbone of Morocco, Algeria & Tunisia

(5, 4).clue: In geology it's a type of erosion; in business it's reducing staff without layoffs

(6, 4).clue: Completes the line Whittier gave Barbara Frietchie: "Shoot, if you must this old grey head, but spare your country's..."

(1, 5).clue: Jesus mentioned "mint and anise and" this spice used in chili powder & curry powder

(3, 5).clue: Balzac described it as "a French island basking in the Italian sun"

(4, 5).clue: A poetic image with an outlandish comparison

(5, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew presents the clue.)  New York State uses 1 trillion cubic feet of natural gas a year; there may be 500 trillion cubic feet within this underground shale formation named for a village near Syracuse

(6, 5).clue: "Thou hast nerved the afric's hand", wrote Whittier in a poem to this abolitionist who published The Liberator

(0, 0).clue: Amazon said this author who died in 2004 was the first to sell a million Kindle e-books
